bibliographic_metadata.Title: Modeling of Cu-Au prospectivity in the Carajás mineral province (Brazil) through machine learning: Dealing with imbalanced training data
bibliographic_metadata.Author: Elias Martins Guerra Prado, Carlos Roberto de Souza Filho, Emmanuel John M. Carranza, João Gabriel Motta

abstract: Machine learning (ML) is becoming an appealing tool in various fields of Earth Sciences, especially in mineral prospectivity mapping (MPM) to support mineral exploration. ML algorithms are designed to assume a relatively balanced amount of training data for the estimation of the decision boundaries between the classes of interest. However, in MPM the numbers of mineralized and non-mineralized locations are naturally imbalanced. The use of imbalanced data leads to difficulties in the training of ML models for MPM. This study evaluates the effects of Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) on the performance of MPM using support vector machine for Cu-Au prospectivity modeling in the Carajás mineral province (Brazil). The results show that SMOTE can significantly increase the performance and spatial efficiency of MPM.
methodology: supervised > kernel-based > support vector machine; knowledge-driven > probabilistic > weights of evidence (WofE)

dataset_fields.scope: Training to application scope: Training data from known mineralized locations to application in predicting prospective areas.

key_points: Machine learning algorithms can improve mineral prospectivity mapping.
Imbalanced training data can lead to biased model performance.
SMOTE significantly enhances the performance of ML models in prospectivity mapping.
The study focuses on Cu-Au deposits in the Carajás mineral province, Brazil.
The best model achieved high classification rates for both training and testing datasets.
